Description: Body sherd of Greek coarse ware pottery vessel, probaby a pithos; exterior: stamped cable pattern decoration; near bottom of sherd, "collar depression". Red-brown silt fabric with grey core and organic inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Fabric is probably Nile Delta silt. However, the design of the stamped decoration is Archaic East Greek. This was probably made in Naukratis.
Eva Simantoni-Bournia (pers.comm.) cites very close parallels from Siphnos, and excludes production outside the Cyclades.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (IA.40)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Purchased in Cairo by M. Jean de Mot
